Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Mapping the Western Foreign Fighter Crisis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Abstract
In this project, the PI proposes to collect and analyze data related to jihadist networks. Using the procedures developed to collect information about Al-Qaeda-inspired networks, this project seeks to expand the scope of the existing project to include ISIL-related networks. In particular, the project seeks to expand upon the existing data collection procedures to include social media and blog posts. The information gathered from this project holds the potential to identify US citizens targeted for recruitment by Jihadist groups. The broader impacts of this work are strong. The data are of potential value to those working in the academic and policy making areas. The PI is well equipped to complete the project, and will employ a team comprised of graduate and undergraduate students to assist in the data collection.


Technical Abstract
This project will result in the maintenance and expansion of the existing Western Jihadism Data Base (WJDB). This data set consists of a combination of individual-level qualitative and quantitative data on people with ties to extremist groups such as ISIL and Al-Qeada. The unique and potentially valuable extension of this project is the plan to incorporate digital data gleaned from more public sources such as social media and blog posting. The end result will be additional entries into and timely of the WJDB. The project is particularly strong with respect to its broader impacts. It has potential to be valuable for policymakers and practitioners who seek to prevent attacks. The PI is highly qualified to complete the project having done significant work on the existing databases. The research team will also be comprised of students, both graduate and undergraduate, giving the project a strong pedagogical component.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Galvanized by the declaration of a dystopian caliphate in territories under the control of ISIL in Syria and Iraq, record numbers of Western militants traveled to the combat zone in 2014 and 2015. By late 2016, ISIL?s proto-state was under growing pressure. Coinciding with the roll-back of its territorial control, the reported number of deaths rose. ISIL staged a growing number of attacks in Europe and encouraged followers who could not travel to the combat zone to join the FTO to ?do something? on their own. There was clearly and opportunity and an urgent need for quick-response data collection and research. An application was made to NSF RAPID for an award to support the collection of data from social media and other public sources, including jihadist media sites and postings by the fighters and their supporters who remained in Europe.

When funding was granted, the PI and her team tracked down and preserved ephemeral data from social media accounts and assembled other documentation, including court documents and reports of legal proceedings, from media and government sources. Undergraduate and graduate research assistants were employed to code demographic and relational data about the travelers and their domestic supporters. Data were encoded and added to an extant online data collection, known as the Western Jihadism Project (WJP). All data derive from public records and are manually coded. The WJP contains a historical archive of quantitative and qualitative data dating back to the early 1990s that documents arrests, conspiracies, and illegal travel by publicly known perpetrators of terrorism of terrorism-related crimes inspired by Al Qaeda and aligned foreign terrorist organizations (FTOs).

About 1,500 new person records have been added to the WJP collection since the start of the project. Some 90% of the new coding concerned individuals who professed loyalty to ISIL. A total of 2,176 persons who acted on behalf of ISIL and their demographic and relational data have been recorded. In addition, extant profiles were updated as new information became available.

The aim of the research is to develop a real-world dataset that is sufficiently large to support the use of social scientific methodologies in the study of terrorist recruitment and networks. Real-world data are non-experimental data associated with verifiable outcomes about the study subjects. Scalable data of this kind is exceedingly rare in the case of ?dark? networks engaging and been an obstacle to theory testing and comparative studies in terrorism studies. The WJP data collection now comprises records for 6,500 Western ?homegrown? terrorism offenders inspired by the jihadist FTOs as well as relational data about their networks, and will provide the basis for a new approach to the use of social scientific methodologies in the study of terrorist organization, recruitment and radicalization,

Several broader impacts may be noted. The project provided opportunities for students in the social sciences to become familiar with computational methods for managing and analyzing data. Two-thirds of the students working on the project were women, as is the PI. In this way, the research provided new opportunities for women in the field.

A key objective was to make the data available for collaborative team-based research. This has now been accomplished as three teams of researchers, two in the United States and one in Germany, now access the data through an innovative web-based data portal maintained by Brandeis University.

Furthermore, the project has led to new collaborations between social scientists and computer scientists. The portal utilizes a relational data management system relying on Structured Query Language (SQL) to coordinate the data tables and to enable users to store, edit and filter, and retrieve data from the web-based data collection. in the Klausen lab Recently, we have started to experiment with machine-learning techniques to scan digitized texts and highlight and extract relevant data from the records. The technology remains error-prone but may eventually assist or even replace manual data entry.

The research has contributed to national security by supporting evidence-based policy decisions. Research based on the WJP has contradicted many popularly held beliefs about the causes of jihadist extremism in the West and changed our understanding of which individuals are likely to present a risk to public safety and social cohesion. An evidence-based approach will minimize the risk of excessive and misdirected counterterrorism enforcement while also minimizing the risks posed by terrorist extremism.
